g.text: Oral tranexamic acid reduces blood loss in
Hua Li, MM, Liqun Bai, MM, Yunhai Li, MM, Zhiyuan Fang, MM
Postoperative hemorrhage following total-knee arthroplasty (TKA) remains an important topic. The objective of the
meta-analysis is to assess the effectiveness of oral anti
brinolytics for blood management in patients undergoing TKA.
We searched Medline (1966 to August 2018), PubMed (1966 to August 2018), Embase (1980 to August 2018),
ScienceDirect (1985 to August 2018), and the Web of Science (1995 to August 2018) for randomized control trials (RCTs). To
assess the heterogeneity of study trial and determine the model for analysis (random-effect model or
Chi-squared were conducted. We utilized the STATA 12.0 (StataCorp, College Station, TX) to perform all statistical analyses.
A total of 5 RCTs met our inclusion criteria. This meta-analysis shows that there are signi
2 groups regarding total blood loss, hemoglobin reduction, and transfusion rates. In addition, no adverse effects were identi
brinolytics in TKA is able to signi
cantly decrease blood loss, postoperative hemoglobin
reduction, as well as transfusion requirements. No increased risk of postoperative complications was observed. Higher quality RCTs
brinolytics, blood loss, meta-analysis, oral, total-knee arthroplasty
Total-knee arthroplasty (TKA) is a common surgical procedure
for treatment of the degenerative disorders and rheumatic
It has been estimated that more than 700,000 TKAs
were performed throughout the United States annually.
However, arthroplasties were associated with substantial
estimated 750 to 1800 mL of calculated total blood loss during
Although various methods such as hemostatic agent
administration, hypothermic anesthesia, tourniquet, and mini-
mally invasive procedures have been used, blood transfusion
rates remain relatively high which may cause hemolysis,
eld of surgery. Tranexamic acid (TXA) is a synthetic analog
of the amino acid lysine and it serves as an anti
Recently, it was widely used in major orthopedic surgery.
Previous articles have demonstrated that it was effective and safe
for patients who received intravenous administration or topical
application of TXA. Alshryda et al
TXA was effective in decreasing blood transfusion rates after
reported that 15 mg/kg of TXA could
cantly decrease the need for postoperative transfusion of
allogeneic blood due to a signi
cant reduction in intra-, post-, and
perioperative blood loss. Indeed, the oral form of TXA was cheap
and easy to use and did not require speci
However, the relatively small amount of patients meant the
results of the present studies were inconclusive and there has been
no systematic evaluation of the literature. Consequently, we
applied a systematic and meta-analytical approach to determine
the evidence for the safety and ef
This systematic review and meta-analysis were conducted
following the PRISMA (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic
Reviews and Meta-Analyses) Statement. No primary personal
data will be collected; therefore no additional ethical approval
The electronic databases of PubMed, Embase, ScienceDirect, and
the Web of Science were searched from the inception of the
database to August 2018, without language restriction. The
following key words were used in combination with Boolean
The authors have no funding and con
